entry.title: Standard ALV Line Selection instead of Checkbox in SAP
entry.content:
In many SAP reports, we build ALV outputs and allow the user to select certain rows for further processing.
A common approach is to add a custom checkbox column in the field catalog and capture user-selected rows.

But did you know?
üëâALV itself provides a built-in line selection mechanism ‚Äî no need for extra checkbox fields.
This makes your report look cleaner and behave more like standard SAP transactions (e.g., ME2N, ME23N).

In this post, I‚Äôll share how to enable row selection both in OOPs ALV (CL_GUI_ALV_GRID) and Classical ALV (REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY), along with the benefits.


OOPs ALV with Container (CL_GUI_ALV_GRID):


Enable Line Selection

DATA: ls_layout TYPE lvc_s_layo.

ls_layout-sel_mode = 'A'.   " A = Multiple

CALL METHOD gr_alvgrid->set_table_for_first_display
  EXPORTING
    is_layout       = ls_layout
  CHANGING
    it_outtab       = gt_final
    it_fieldcatalog = gt_fcat.

 Fetch Selected Rows

DATA: lt_rows TYPE lvc_t_row,
      ls_row  TYPE lvc_s_row,
      lv_index TYPE sy-tabix.

CALL METHOD gr_alvgrid->get_selected_rows
  IMPORTING
    et_index_rows = lt_rows.   " selected row indices

LOOP AT lt_rows INTO ls_row.
  lv_index = ls_row-index.         " Index in GT_FINAL
  READ TABLE gt_final INDEX lv_index INTO DATA(ls_final).
  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    " ---> Do your processing with ls_final
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.



Classical ALV (REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY)

Define Layout & Call ALV

DATA: ls_layout TYPE slis_layout_alv.
ls_layout-sel_mode = 'A'.  " A = Multiple

CALL FUNCTION 'REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY'
  EXPORTING
    i_callback_program      = sy-repid
    i_callback_user_command = 'USER_COMMAND'
    is_layout               = ls_layout
    it_fieldcat             = gt_fcat
  TABLES
    t_outtab                = gt_final.

 Handle User Command

FORM user_command USING r_ucomm     LIKE sy-ucomm
                        rs_selfield TYPE slis_selfield.

  DATA: lt_rows TYPE slis_t_row,
        ls_row  TYPE slis_row,
        ls_final TYPE your_table_type,
        lr_grid TYPE REF TO cl_gui_alv_grid.

  CASE r_ucomm.

    WHEN 'SUBMIT'.  " Custom button
      CALL FUNCTION 'GET_GLOBALS_FROM_SLVC_FULLSCR'
        IMPORTING e_grid = lr_grid.

      CALL METHOD lr_grid->get_selected_rows
        IMPORTING et_index_rows = lt_rows.

      LOOP AT lt_rows INTO ls_row.
        READ TABLE gt_final INDEX ls_row-index INTO ls_final.
        IF sy-subrc = 0.
          " -> process ls_final
        ENDIF.
      ENDLOOP.
  ENDCASE.
ENDFORM.

 
Advantages over Checkbox Selection

  1. Cleaner UI ‚Äì No need to add an extra checkbox column.

  2. Standard SAP Behavior ‚Äì Works like ME2N/ME23N where row selection is natural.

  3. Multiple Modes ‚Äì Single row, multiple row, column, or cell selection possible.

  4. Event Driven ‚Äì Double-click events can directly trigger detailed processing.

  5. Less Code ‚Äì No need to manage an extra field (X/space) for selection.

 

Conclusion

Whenever you design ALV reports, prefer standard line selection instead of custom checkbox fields.
It not only reduces development effort but also gives your users a familiar SAP standard look and feel.

Let me know if anyone tries this or if there's a better way to optimise it. I hope this helps! Let me know your thoughts or if you have any questions.

Thanks,

Akshay Anil   Linkedin Profile
Technical Consultant, SAP ABAP | BTP | Fiori | Ui5

#ABAP #SAP #SAPABAP #ABAPTips #SelectionScreen #SAPGUI #UIDesign #SAPCommunity

The catalog you are trying to access is now deprecated in public cloud. However, you have the possibility to use its replacement SAP_CMD_BC_BUSINESS_PARTNER_PC. This provides the same mass changes of business partners functionality (App ID F3774) and standard business partners apps.

Authorization Concept for Business Users

How to Handle Deprecated Business Catalogs

entry.title: Migrate Your SAP Landscape Onto Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Gurus,

i wanna to share with you today a dilemma topics regarding SAP migration onto the Cloud. The question today isn't if you should move your SAP landscape to the cloud or not, but HOW? to do it strategically and efficiently.

Your SAP system is the backbone of your business; your finance, your supply chain, your core data. Moving it is a journey that requires expertise, precision, strong methodology and partnership.

Migration Approaches

The 6Rs migration strategy helps you understand and prioritize portfolio and application discovery, planning, change management, and the technical processes involved in migrating your SAP system to the cloud. The 6 Rs represent six strategies listed in the following table that help you plan for your application migrations.

R strategy

Methodology

Rehosting

The application is migrated as is to AWS. This is also called a "lift-and-shift" approach.

Re-platforming

The application is changed or transformed in some aspect as part of its migration to AWS.

Repurchasing

You move to a different application or solution on the cloud.

Refactoring / Re‚Äëarchitecting

The application is redesigned (for example, it‚Äôs converted from a monolithic architecture to microservices) as part of the migration to AWS.

Retiring

The application is retired during migration to AWS.

Retaining

The application isn‚Äôt migrated.

The decision tree diagram helps you visualize the end-to-end process, starting from application discovery and moving through each 6 R strategy.

 The three strategies that are specifically applicable for SAP migrations to cloud are Rehosting, Re-platforming and Re-Architect.

  • Rehosting is applicable when you want to move your SAP system AS-IS to the cloud hosting. This type of migration involves minimal change and can be seen as a natural fit for customers who are already running some sort of SAP systems.
  • Re-platforming is applicable when you want to migrate from an anyDB source database (such as IBM DB2, Oracle Database, or SQL Server) to an SAP HANA database.
  • Re-Architect (or Transform) This is the most transformative path. This includes two major scenarios:
    • Greenfield: A clean slate implementation of S/4HANA directly on cloud hosting. This is for complete process redesign.
    • Brownfield: Where you upgrade your existing SAP ECC system to S/4HANA while migrating it to AWS. This keeps your historical data and existing business processes, but modernized.

The Business Imperative Beyond Infrastructure

So why are thousands of companies migrating their mission-critical SAP systems to the cloud? It goes far beyond simply replacing a data center. It's about achieving four core business outcomes:

  1. Cost & TCO Reduction: By shifting to the cloud offerings like pay-as-you-go model, you eliminate the crippling cycle of hardware refreshes. You can easily right-size environments, utilize reserved instances for deep discounts, and drastically reduce your Total Cost of Ownership.
  2. Agility & Innovation: This is where the magic happens. Moving SAP onto cloud gives you immediate access to other cloud services like AI, Machine Learning, IoT, and Advanced Analytics. This allows you to rapidly innovate on top of your core SAP data in ways that were impossible on-premise.
  3. Performance & Scalability: cloud hosting usually offers the largest, most powerful certified instances for SAP ERP. This means faster reports, quicker transaction processing, and the ability to instantly scale up for month-end closes or peak demand periods, and then scale back down to save cost.
  4. Security & Resilience: all cloud hosting providers, provides a foundational security layer that is unparalleled, and our architecture ensures high availability, disaster recovery, and compliance, giving your teams peace of mind.

End-to-End Migration From Strategy to Success

 The methodology is a robust, four-phase framework; Assess, Mobilize, Migrate, and Optimize, it's designed to de-risk your entire journey.

  1. Assess: We begin with a deep dive. A discovery workshop, a complete inventory of your SAP landscape, and defining non-functional requirements like Recovery Point Objectives/Recovery Time Objectives. The goal is to produce a precise, tailored architecture and cost model. Conduct transfer knowledge sessions with internal team to be able to operate the SAP landscape on the cloud.
  2. Mobilize: This is the planning and preparation stage. We conduct technical validation, create a detailed migration plan, execute all prerequisites checks, and importantly, on-board and upskill your teams, ensuring a smooth transition of ownership post-migration.
  3. Migrate: The execution phase. We utilize best-in-class tools and zero-downtime techniques where possible, ensuring business continuity throughout the process.
  4. Optimize: This is continuous value realization. We move from just running SAP to reducing cost through rightsizing, minimizing future risk, and increasing organizational agility by leveraging cloud services.

The benefits are clear: Reduce TCO, Minimize Risk, Increase Agility, and Innovate. We measure our success not by the project completion date, but by the realization of these benefits in your business.

Targeted Business Outcomes of Migrating SAP to Cloud

 This figure shows the full scope of business outcomes you can achieve once your core SAP systems are modernized on the cloud. Think of your SAP data flowing seamlessly into the cloud, unlocking potential in every direction:

  • Cost Reduction & Data Center Retirement: The immediate, tangible saving by eliminating technical debt and shifting from CaPx to OpEx.
  • Performance & Auto-scaling: Dramatically faster operations and environments that automatically adjust to workload, guaranteeing peak performance during critical business cycles.
  • Agility and Staff Productivity: By offloading infrastructure management to our managed services, your highly skilled IT staff can dedicate their time to high-value projects, not maintenance.
  • Digital Transformation (SAP S/4HANA): This infrastructure is the perfect foundation for a future S/4HANA transformation, leveraging the speed of HANA and the elasticity of cloud hosting.
  • Data and Analytics: The critical ability to integrate your SAP data with the vast array of cloud analytical tools like SAC, Amazon Redshift or MS PowerBI, to gain deep, competitive business insights and complex data science applications.
  • Improved Security and Resilience: A globally secure and highly available platform that meets stringent compliance requirements.
  • Industry Solutions: With SAP migration onto cloud, you will not just benefit from cloud hosting or cloud services only; but you will gain the benefit of utilize a lot of business solution that leverage your business operations and streamline your business applications platform and all are running onto cloud and integrates together to leverage your business performance and efficiency.

Hope my thoughts useful for you and guide you to the right decision üëç

thank you all and wish you a smooth and successful migration.

#Conversion #Migration SAP HANA

entry.title: Re: Customer Master Data - SAP S/4 HANA PUBLIC CLOUD
entry.content:
Hello @Tehreem_Fatima1 

Thank you for your question

Best solution : Use SAP Credit Management (Financial Supply Chain Management, FSCM) with a single parent credit account shared across all child customers.

In Manage Credit Accounts, set the parent‚Äôs credit segment limit to 100,000 and assign all child Business Partners to it. Any order from a child uses the same limit; if exposure is insufficient, the credit check blocks the document and you release or not in Documented Credit Decisions. SAP Help Portal-Receivables Management-Manage Credit Accounts

If you still want a contract control (secondary)

A  Value Contract at 100,000 (parent as Sold-To, children as Ship-To) will stop releases only when orders reference the contract; monitor with Value Contract Consumption. Use this as an additional commercial control, not the primary enforcement.

Upload and mass handling

For the Credit Management design: use Migrate Your Data ‚Äì Migration Cockpit to load the parent credit account and limit, as well as the child BP assignments, in a single pass. SAP-SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit - Migrate your Data to SAP S/4HANA

To upload multiple Ship-To (SH) addresses for a single Sold-To (AG) when using contracts or partner mapping, utilise the Customer migration object and complete the Sales Area ‚Üí Partner Functions sheet. SAP Help Portal-Available Migration Objects

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Replacement of string '&3' not possible in CDS View
entry.content:
Be careful if you use many nested expressions.

Split in small pieces and you'll see the problem:

cast(
  replace(
    cast(
      replace(
        cast(
          replace(
            cast(
              replace(
                Text, 
                '&1', 
                cast(value1 as abap.char(20)))
              abap.char(73)),
            '&2', 
            cast(value2 as abap.char(20)))
          as abap.char(73)),
        cast('&3' as abap.sstring(50)),
      cast(value3 as abap.char(20)))
    as abap.char(76)),
  '&4', 
  cast(value4 as abap.char(20))) 
as abap.char(76)) as MessageText

entry.title: Re: Taking Back Components from Subcontractor via Inbound...
SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition ‚Äì Usage Anomaly Detection
entry.content:
SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition ‚Äì Usage Anomaly Detection

See beyond the known patterns

New Feature

Public

October 2025

Working Within the Known Patterns

Imagine a company called ZingCharge, an electric vehicle (EV) charging provider with partner charging stations in various locations. Each station has multiple charging points where customers can park and charge their EVs.

ZingCharge has an annual revenue of ‚Ç¨100 million and offers a subscription service called CHARGEASYOUGO. This service allows subscribers to charge their vehicles for a fee at any ZingCharge-affiliated station. Then ZingCharge uses the charge session information to:

  • Invoice subscribers at the end of the month for the electric charging consumption used irrespective of where and which partner has been used.
  • Settle with these partners using the same charging session information.

ZingCharge‚Äôs Problem

ZingCharge uses static validation rules capabilities of SAP Convergent Mediation, public cloud edition. However, these static rules aren‚Äôt enough to capture hidden data issues beyond the known patterns (e.g., faulty sensors). Therefore they are facing challenges due to inefficiencies in its billing and revenue tracking processes, making it difficult to identify issues without significant manual effort.

  • Manual monitoring: 30 person-days (costly)
  • Manual troubleshooting: 60 person-days (costly)
  • Invoice delays (Days Sales Outstanding): 10 days
  • Revenue leakage due to poor data quality: ‚Ç¨1M (1% of revenue).
  • Poor customer experience: NPS degradation, reduced upsell, potential churn

Key persona perspective

How to Solve for Billing Accuracy

Wherever there‚Äôs usage based-billing, for example measuring services consumed, e.g., ‚ÄúkWh‚Äù in Utilities, ‚ÄúGigabytes‚Äù in Telecom or ‚ÄúAPI calls‚Äù in Software as a Service ‚Äì there‚Äôs always a cost associated with inaccurate bills reaching the customer.

  • Either the customer is overcharged, which increases the risk of dispute management efforts, customer churn, and reputation damage.
  • Alternatively, the customer is undercharged, and there‚Äôs risk of revenue leakage and setting unreasonable customer expectations. 

Trying to solve the accuracy problems further downstream in billing requires high manual efforts, which are both slow and costly from a labor perspective, with the following risks:

  • Delaying the delivery of bills to the customers and subsequent collection of payments, increasing the Days Sales Outstanding (DSO), which adds further cost to the process and decreases cash flow.
  • Overwhelming billing operations with manual corrections of bills during intensive (and delayed) bill-runs ‚Äì time spent better on more strategic work.
  • Frustrating the customers with long dispute management process and credit correction memos.
  • Undercharging the customer due to undetected anomalies, leading to revenue leakage.

Early detection of potential data problems during the mediation process addresses these billing operations risks. It does so by flagging suspicious data records continuously as potential anomalies for billing operations inspection. This allows the billing operations team to apply corrective actions in billing as soon as the anomalies are detected, throughout the month, allowing correct bills to reach the customers in a timely manner with less manual effort.

The picture below shows in the top lane how a typical customer uses mediation today, with static validation rules, correcting the data quality issues in billing in a highly manual way. In the bottom lane, it‚Äôs shown how a customer by adding Usage Anomaly Detection can automate parts of their billing accuracy process and improve the business outcomes.

Example Classic Bill Run vs with SAP Convergent Mediation + Usage Anomaly Detection

How Can Usage Anomaly Detection Improve Data Quality?

The feature is designed to take the mediation data quality to the next level by addressing the so-called ‚ÄúKnown-unknowns‚Äù. I.e., the usage data problems we know exist, but we don‚Äôt know how to capture with traditional static validation rules. Here, the machine learning algorithms extend the error detection capabilities of mediation. 

The ‚ÄúKnown-knowns‚Äù are issues that we have high awareness of and know how to address, typically solved through validation rules and reprocessing in mediation.

Overview of new types of data problems addressable with combined machine learning and billing operations analysis.

What‚Äôs the New Feature?

Today, SAP Convergent Mediation, public cloud edition, already captures many types of known errors with static validation rules and allows them to be classified, managed in Data Correction facility and corrected in bulk. The new Usage Anomaly Detection feature enables additional types of data issues to be detected and resolved.

The new feature in a nutshell:

  • Out-of-the-box Usage Anomaly Detection feature powered by machine learning to identify patterns and detect anomalies within usage data streams.
  • This predictive capability helps organizations proactively identify potential issues, unusual consumption patterns, and data quality concerns before they impact business operations.
  • When potential anomalies are detected, the system leverages GenAI to generate detailed analyses of each anomaly.
  • These AI-generated analyses are displayed within the Usage intelligence dashboard, providing users with immediate, actionable insights.
  • Additionally, this analysis can be shared with relevant stakeholders via email, ensuring that key individuals are promptly informed and able to respond as needed.

 

Overview of usage data flowing through mediation and Usage Anomaly Detection

Customer Onboarding Process

Below are the typical steps in the onboarding process for current SAP Convergent Mediation, public cloud edition, customers in enabling this Usage Anomaly Detection feature.

  • Activate the Usage Anomaly Detection package in their tenant via an SAP4Me ‚ÄúService Request‚Äù.
  • Create one or more streams that forward the training data sets via the Usage Intelligence forwarder function in the required format (at least 15 days‚Äô worth of data).
  • In the background, the DigitalRoute team will set up the Machine Learning pipelines for each type of data (e.g, kWh, Gigabytes, API Calls).
  • Tune the Machine Learning pipeline through several iterations. This is normally a joint exercise with the DigitalRoute team, where large sets of data are used to reach maximum accuracy (ideally up to 90 days of usage data).
  • Once DigitalRoute team have tuned the models to desired accuracy, the Usage Anomaly Detection function is ready for production use.

How Does the User Interact with Usage Anomaly Detection?

Below is an example scenario, where the customer, an Electric Vehicle charging provider, has setup Usage Anomaly Detection on their charging stations and attached charging points. The purpose is to capture unexpected patterns early in the mediation process, due to for example, faulty sensors or fraud attempts and address the proactively in billing. 

1. Customer configures Billing Operations email address to receive potential anomaly notifications ‚Äì  the emails include links to anomalies for Billing Operations to inspect.

E-mail notification of Potential Anomaly for Billing Operations Inspections

2. The links leads to the Usage Anomaly Detection Business Dashboard, with an overview of the new, unhandled, and handled anomalies. As well as individual and groups of data sources with most anomalies.

Business Dashboard ‚Äì Anomaly Overview

3. From the Business Dashboard, Billing Operations can go to the new anomaly overview, from where they can select the most interesting one (highest probability and high value). 

Business Dashboard ‚Äì Drill-Down View of Anomalies with Probability and Value

4. There they will see a detailed screen with GenAI description of the anomaly and graphed usage. They can also zoom out the usage, for example over three months, for the operator to get a better understanding. 

Business Dashboard ‚Äì Historic Usage and Generative AI Description of Anomaly

5. From there, Billing Operations can mark the inspected anomaly as confirmed anomaly or as normal. If marked as confirmed anomaly, the operator can send an email from the Business Dashboard to a support email address for investigation.

Business Dashboard ‚Äì Detailed Graph of Historic Usage over Three Months

Moreover, the Business Dashboard allows the operator persona to share anomalies to be checked with Support and other relevant colleagues with a few clicks and send a mail with GenAI generated natural language description of the issue. 

Conclusion

Key Benefits of Usage Anomaly Detection:

  • Proactive Issue Detection: Identifies usage data anomalies early in the mediation process, preventing errors from being addressed continuously after they are detected.
  • Reduced Manual Effort: Automates Usage Anomaly Detection and explanation, minimizing the need for time-consuming manual investigations and corrections.
  • Revenue Protection: Helps prevent both overcharging and undercharging, reducing revenue leakage and the risk of customer disputes and churn.
  • Faster, More Accurate Billing: Accelerates billing cycles and improves invoice accuracy, leading to quicker payments and enhanced customer satisfaction.
  • Actionable Insights and Collaboration: Provides easy-to-understand, GenAI-powered resolution across billing teams.

Quantified Business Outcomes of Usage Anomaly Detection:

  • 60% reduction in revenue leakage by proactively addressing usage data issues.
  • 90% less manual effort required to resolve dependencies in quote-to-cash cycle.

Figures are based on customer proof-of-concept project performed in 2024/2025.

Key Persona helped by the Usage Anomaly Detection feature

Further readings

  • Usage Intelligence - Usage Engine Cloud Edition Documentation - InfoZone (DigitalRoute InfoZone)
  • Usage anomaly detection - Usage Engine Cloud Edition Documentation - InfoZone (DigitalRoute InfoZone)

entry.title: S/4HANA Cloud CBO logic: Read BP Attachment, Base64, and store as 500-char chunks?
entry.content:
System: SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition and Private Edition
Extensibility: Key-User Custom Business Object (CBO) 

Preparation step: A PDF is attached to the Business Partner with filename

Desired behavior (in CBO logic)

  1. Read the BP attachment

  2. Encode binary to Base64.

  3. Split into 500-character parts.

  4. Save those parts into CBO(multiple rows/items).

Questions for the community

  1. Is there a released (whitelisted) API that CBO key-user logic can call to read a Business Partner attachment by filename or attachment ID?

  2. Are HTTP/OData calls allowed from CBO logic for this purpose?
  3. If direct read from CBO logic is not supported, what is the recommended pattern?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: Freight unit stage remains blocked for planning with...
entry.content:
Received answer from SAP. 

in advanced STO the advanced stage building is executed and during this, the selling party company code and org. id is evaluated. Both fields had to be filled in the TM data. The system was not able to determine company code and org. id data during mapping of delivery data to TM data based on the involved company codes as database table /SCMB/HRP5561 did not have records for them. Since the selling party company code and org. id are not available, the stage is marked as not relevant for planning.

Maintain these in PPOCE and include the BSG Org unit and you're good to go.

entry.title: What's new in SAP Logistics Management
entry.content:
SAP Logistics Management is our new solution in Supply Chain Management that combines warehousing‚ÄØand transportation management‚ÄØto streamline your operations‚ÄØwith network-centric collaboration. In SAP Logistics Management, new features are released on a bi-weekly basis. 

In this blog post, you will learn about the new features in SAP Logistics Management that have been released today. 

 

Change Destination Bin on Warehouse Task Confirmation

With this release, we have enabled the functionality to confirm warehouse tasks with changes. When you open a warehouse task, the button ‚ÄúConfirm with Changes‚Äù is available at the top right corner. You can use this button during task confirmation to change the destination bin. 

Further changes (e.g. change of quantity) will be supported soon.  

 

Warehouse Task Creation via Dialog

In order to improve the user experience, warehouse task creation in inbound, outbound and via the "Manage Stock" app is now possible via a dialog:  

 

Joule Available in SAP Logistics Management

With this release, the integration of Joule into SAP Logistics Management is available. It helps you to interact with your business applications in natural language to streamline your workflow and enhance productivity. 

  • Natural Language Interaction: Communicate your business needs effortlessly by using natural language. Joule understands your requirements and helps you navigate your applications swiftly, ensuring seamless execution of your business processes.
  • Instant Insights: Gain quick access to your business data, such as logistical demands and warehouse tasks, without the hassle of searching and opening multiple applications. Joule provides you with the insights you need, when you need them.
  • Efficient Task Management: Joule assists you in creating or updating business data, enabling you to complete daily tasks more efficiently. Whether it's performing freight tendering tasks or managing other logistical operations, Joule is your reliable partner in productivity.
  • Custom-Fit Answers: Have questions? Ask Joule in natural language and receive tailored answers from Joule, leveraging the comprehensive documentation available in the SAP Help Portal for SAP Logistics Management.
 
How to set up and configure the AI copilot Joule for interaction with SAP Logistics Management?
Check the Setup and Adminstration Guide for SAP Logistics Management
 
What Joule capabilities can you expect in SAP Logistics Management? 
Check the Joule Capabilites Guide

 

Deletion of Empty Shipping Handling Units

To improve workspace clarity and operational efficiency in the Packing Work Center, this feature introduces the ability to delete unused or accidentally created shipping handling units (HUs). It is enabled through a delete action (bin icon) added to each HU header and supports singular deletion of empty HUs.

 

Business Rule for Consolidation Cutoff - Additional input parameters

To provide a flexible but harmonized set of conditions across the different business rules, the business rule for consolidation cutoff (CONSOLIDATION_CUTOFF_SCHEDULE_DET_V1) has been enhanced by the following parameters: route, ship to party, shipping condition, and shipping point.

 

View 3D Warehouse Layout

With this feature, you can perform the following actions using the ‚ÄúView 3D Warehouse Layout‚Äù app:

  • View the graphical 3D warehouse layout with interactive features like zooming, rotating, panning, and viewing from predetermined camera angles.
  • Search for specific storage bins and access detailed information by choosing the storage bin directly on the graphical layout.
  • Update and regenerate the 3D graphical layout using the latest storage bin data.

 

Audit Logging Integration for Import of Organizational Model

This feature integrates the central audit logging service to track organizational model changes. It supports auditors by providing a reliable log of configuration changes and security events, such as malware detection during organizational model imports.

 

Visibility of Freight Request for Quotation ID and Freight Quotation ID for Shipper

Freight Request for Quotation ID and Freight Quotation ID are now part of the app "Manage Freight Tendering" hereby supporting Shipper and Carrier collaboration. 

In addition, the search of Freight Tender is now possible trough providing the Freight Request for Quotation ID as filter. 

 

Further Information

SAP Logistics Management Product Page

SAP Logistics Management Learning Session

entry.title: Stock Transport Order - Integration options within S/4HANA logistics (with SD, LE, TM, EWM)
entry.content:
Recently I have evaluated available & supported scanarios for handling the stock transport process in S/4HANA. Depending on the S/4 release, deployment option and logistical process requirements several combinations are possible (along with respective restrictions). In the below overview I would like to share my insights based on the latest on-premise S/4 release (2023). The available options are listed but not explained in full detail as to the required configuration & process steps. These aspects have been already covered in some excellent blog contributions and in SAP documentation. I will try to keep the overview up to date - as with new releases new options and features should be available. 

The  STO Stock Transport Order process handles moving goods between plants or storage locations within company (within the same company code: intra-company, between different company codes: inter-company). Depending on the process there might be a need to leverage transportation management for transportation related processes (planning, execution, freight costs settlement & distribution etc.) and warehouse management (pick, pack, stage, load etc.). In SAP application landscape this would translate to using TM and/or EWM to cover such requirements.

There are various options in S/4HANA on-premise (embedded deployment) as of today, some are supported (with restrictions) and some are still a to-do on SAP roadmap:

  1. Classic STO (Best Practice Scope Item: 1P9) - process with Intercompany Purchase order, Outbound delivery (Delivering Company) and Inbound delivery (Receiving Company):
    1. Classic STO with TM: supported
    2. Classic STO with TM + active ASR (Advanced Shipping and Receiving): supported
    3. Classic STO with EWM: supported
    4. Classic STO with TM & EWM with TU-based integration: supported
    5. Classic STO with TM & EWM with Advanced Shipping & Receiving: supported
  1. Advanced STO (Best Practice Scope Item: 5HP) - Process with Intercompany Purchase order, Intercompany Sales order, Outbound delivery (Delivering Company), Inbound delivery (Receiving Company): Advanced intercompany stock transfer is available with SAP S/4HANA 2022 onwards (downport is not possible).
    1. Advanced STO with TM: supported
    2. Advanced STO with EWM:  supported
    3. Advanced STO with TM & EWM with TU-based integration: not yet supported
    4. Advanced STO with TM & EWM with Advanced Shipping & Receiving: not yet supported

Below some additional information on the listed options:

I.1. Classic STO with TM:  For the outbound and inbound deliveries created in the classic STO, in TM corresponding Freight Units are created. The speciality in the TM STO scenario is that the corresponding TM freight units are reassigned from the outbound to the inbound delivery.

In the classic two-step STO scenario, only the replenishment (outbound) delivery will be TM relevant while the inbound delivery created using the SPED output type out of the outbound delivery will not be TM relevant and this a standard behavior of TM before S/4HANA 2022.  Starting from S/4HANA 2022 FPS01, the inbound delivery will receive a TM Control Key but there is no FU building in TM. SAP Documentation: TM Integration of Stock Transport Orders

I.2. Classic STO with TM with active ASR (Advanced Shipping and Receiving):  Starting from S/4HANA 2022 FPS01, for STOs in Advanced Shipping and Receiving scenario without EWM, the posting of goods issue in the outbound delivery triggers the creation of an SPED inbound delivery and the automatic reassignment of the FUs from the outbound to the inbound delivery in Delivery Management. So, if both outbound and inbound delivery are relevant for ASR AND both locations are not managed by EWM - this case leads to reassignment. Note 3118823: Inbound delivery created via SPED is not TM relevant

I.3. Classic STO with EWM: For the outbound and inbound deliveries created in the classic STO, in EWM a corresponding outbound delivery order and an inbound delivery order get created and processed. There can be two EWM-managed warehouses involved: one for the Delivering/Supplying plant (outbound)  and one for the Receiving Plant (Inbound delivery).

I.4. Classic STO with TM & EWM with TU-based integration: The integration of Transportation Management (TM) with Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) based on EWM transportation units (TUs) supports processes with stock transport orders (STOs). The prerequisite is that Delivery Management and Transportation Management must run on the same system. Check: Note 3018355: Supported functional scope and restrictions of the TU-based TM EWM Integration for shippers and SAP Documentation: STO process - Integration Based on EWM Transportation Units

I.5. Classic STO with TM & EWM with ASR: In case of classic STO (two-step process) if both OBD and IBD are relevant for ASR AND both locations are managed by EWM - this scenario is now also supported with the newest S/4HANA release 2025: in this scenario TM Freight Units are reassigned from the OBD-FU to the IBD-FU.  

Please refer to Enablement of STO Execution with EWM Warehouse for the following scenario variants:

  • Outbound ASR shipping point and EWM storage location (SLOC) to inbound ASR shipping point and EWM storage location
  • Outbound ASR and EWM SLOC to inbound ASR and non-EWM storage location
  • Outbound ASR and non-EWM SLOC to inbound ASR and EWM storage location
  • Outbound non-ASR and non-EWM SLOC to inbound ASR and EWM storage location

II.1. Advanced STO with TM:  SAP TM is not a mandatory for the advanced intercompany stock transfer. However, updates on the planned and actual dates and times for transfer of control based on Incoterms (relevant for handling the valuated stock in transfer) are not possible without SAP TM. SAP Documentation: TM Integration of Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer

II.2. Advanced STO with EWM: in general the already available EWM configuration for handling the outbound as well as inbound delivery integration is sufficient. There is no configuration specific to  advanced intercompany stock transfer for EWM.

Please note that the valuated stock-in-transit is not supported in EWM-managed warehouses or storage locations: Note 3376453: Release information and Restrictions embedded EWM S4HANA 2023  and Note: 1822497: FAQ: LE restrictions for valuated stock in transit (SiT)

II.3. Advanced STO with TM & EWM: with TU-based integration & II.4. Advanced STO with TM & EWM with ASR:  The integration of advanced STO with TM is not supported in combination with Warehouse Outbound Processing (scope item 3BS) and/or Warehouse Inbound Processing (3BR). This scenario should be supported by SAP it the future: SAP Roadmap: Planned for Q1 2026:  Advanced intercompany stock transfer (5HP) with warehouse management and transportation management (outbound) However, there is no specific information as to which TM/EWM integration approach (TU-led vs. ASR) will be realized.

To summarize, both STO scenarios available in S/4HANA do integrate with TM and EWM but each with different configuration, availability and restrictions. Choosing the right option should be therefore an informed decision and I hope this overview is useful in that respect. Any comments / corrections / Your views on this  are much appreciated.

entry.title: Re: Questions on using Terraform with SAP BTP Trial Account
entry.content:
Hi @mare42,

Thank you for your response! I managed to create a Cloud Foundry instance in my trial BTP account with the required org memory. The quotas were configured at the global account level.

Before creating the Cloud Foundry instance, I set up the quota in the subaccount as follows:

resource "btp_subaccount_entitlement" "cf_memory" {
  subaccount_id = btp_subaccount.project_subaccount.id
  service_name  = "APPLICATION_RUNTIME"
  plan_name     = "MEMORY"
  amount        = 4
}

resource "btp_subaccount_environment_instance" "cloudfoundry" {
  subaccount_id    = btp_subaccount.project_subaccount.id
  name             = local.subaccount_cf_org
  environment_type = "cloudfoundry"
  service_name     = "cloudfoundry"
  plan_name        = "trial"
  landscape_label  = terraform_data.cf_landscape_label.output
  parameters = jsonencode({
    instance_name = local.subaccount_cf_org
  })
  depends_on       = [btp_subaccount_entitlement.cf_memory]
}

Regarding the second point, I agree with your suggestion. Do you have any ideas or examples of how to retrieve the custom IDP URL using Terraform (Cloud Identity Services - IAS one)?

Thank you again for your help!

Best regards

entry.title: Re: SAP PP or SAP MM
entry.content:
Given your strong hands-on experience with SAP PP/MM and your interest in SAP, specializing in either SAP PP or MM is a solid next step‚Äîbut MM may offer broader career flexibility and integration opportunities.

Here‚Äôs a breakdown to help you decide and explore your options:

Why MM might be more versatile for you:

  • MM is implemented in nearly every SAP environment, making it more transferable across industries.
  • Your experience with purchase requisitions, MIGO, and service entries aligns well with MM‚Äôs core functions.
  • MM integrates well with SD (Sales & Distribution), which opens doors to customer-facing roles and supply chain optimization.

entry.title: Financial Planned Data in Professional Services ‚Äì by Project Financial Booklet
entry.content:
In this blog post we will explain how the plan categories are used in the customer project scenario tailored for professional services. We will also explain how the plan data is calculated and updated in ACDOCP, and how they can be reported with the Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services app.

enjoy

Chenchu Zhong and Stefan Walz

In customer project management, staying on top of budgets and costs is essential for ensuring profitability and meeting client expectations, especially in fixed-price billing scenarios. Multiple planning versions help monitor the original plan and track changes that arise from resource allocation or scope adjustments. Additionally, we use the financial plan data for the POC calculation in Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR). In the Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services app, we have enabled the display of all planned data versions for customer projects, ensuring full visibility and transparency. In this blog post, we‚Äôll explain what each plan category means, and which is updated in ACDOCP. We will explain the calculations and applications of planned data in the project-based services scenario, including Baseline Planned Data (PRO01), Ongoing Planned Data (PRO02), EAC Planned Data (PRO03), EBRR Planned Data (REVREC01), Manual Plan Category, and Virtual Plan Category.

Let‚Äôs use a fixed-price customer project as our example, where multiple planning data versions may be available to track and manage costs.

Baseline Planned Data

CPM Baseline planned data (Plan category PRO01) represents a snapshot of the initial project plan that records the contract conditions under which the project was started.

This version is technically created when the project moves to the ‚ÄúIn Execution‚Äù stage.

Ongoing Planned Data

CPM Ongoing planned data (Plan category PRO02) reflects the current planning adjustment of the project. During the execution phase, project managers can update planned resources and expenses using the Plan Customer Projects app, which then updates the ongoing planned data. To ensure the ongoing planned data is reflected in financials, it is important to select ‚ÄúSync with Finance‚Äù under the ‚ÄúVersion‚Äù tab.

In the project example, the baseline planned data matches the ongoing planned data (referred to as ‚Äúcurrent‚Äù), as no changes have been made to the ongoing planned version.

Figure 1 Manual ACDOCP update of baseline planned data and ongoing planned data in the Plan Customer Projects app

By choosing ‚ÄúSync with Finance‚Äù, the ongoing planned data is updated in financials (ACDOCP). In the Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services app, both the baseline planned data, and ongoing planned data can be viewed.

Figure 2 Display baseline planned data and ongoing planned data in the Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services app

The service cost rate is maintained by the overhead accountant in the Manage Cost Rate ‚Äì Services app. The cost rates are determined for each resource plan item by the company code/ service org, the role/activity type, work item, or PERNR if assigned.

The time planning is done based on role/activity type. The hours are distributed by the system over the months the project is running. This distribution can be adjusted manually. The system derives the cost rate for each planning period and calculates the amount by multiplied hours of the period with the cost rate of the period.

The plan data in the customer project application are always shown in the project currency. If there is an own project currency applied for the project which deviates from the company code currency, or if there are cost rates maintained in a different currency because intercompany resources are planned, there is a currency conversion done with a monthly P rate occurs by default. However, you can change the currency conversion type in the configuration of the plan category.

The plan revenue is determined in the fixed price project by the billing plan amount.

CPM application sends the data to ACDOCP with transaction currency = project currency. If there is a conversion required, at least for group currency, then ACDOCP converts with a monthly P rate (default configuration in plan categories)

EAC Planned Data

CPM EAC planned data (plan category PRO03), is an estimated total cost of a project on completion, combining actual costs incurred to date with forecasts for remaining effort and expenditures.

While baseline and ongoing plan only take the resource planning into account, the EAC calculation considers deviations between actual and plan.

  • Key Components:
    • Actual Costs (AC): What has been spent so far (read from ACDOCA)
    • Estimate to Completion (ETC): Projected costs to complete tasks still in progress.
    • Estimate at Completion (EAC): Actual Costs (AC) + Estimate to Completion (ETC).
  • Calculation:
    • Actual Costs (AC) = read from ACDOA, no calculation
    • Estimate to Completion (ETC)

The ETC calculation works the following:

  1. First planned costs in project currency are calculated:
    The planned quantity per period is multiplied with the cost rate per period.
    If the cost rate currency is different to the project currency, the currency conversion is done with P rate, which is valid at the beginning of the period.
  2. Then calculate the ETC cost based on customer project data as follows:
    (Planned Hours-Actual Hours) / Planned Hours √ó Planned Cost in Project Currency
  3. Remark: this is done for each expense type

The actuals are read from ACDOCA. To get plan costs in project currency, the object currency is read.

See https://me.sap.com/notes/3547953/E for details on how ETC and EAC calculation works.

The calculated EAC will be different to the original CPM plan, if the following occurs:

  1. You record more than the total planned hours allocated for the planned activity type/role (This applies regardless of who logged the hours, as along as they belong to the planned activity type)
  2. Hours are logged under an unplanned/unassigned activity type/role, work item, or service organization
  3. Post unplanned expenses, e.g., travel expenses

In the Review Customer Projects app, the project manager can adjust the ETC values based on forecasted efforts (quantities) required to complete the project.

For the example project, the junior consultant has already recorded 5 hours of work, resulting in actual costs of 5 hours multiplied by the service cost rate of 50 EUR/h, equating to 250 EUR. The ETC quantity for the junior consultant is currently 5 hours based on the current plan.

Figure 3 Review EAC values in the app Review Customer Projects

However, the project manager reassesses the situation and determines that the 5 hours allocated for the junior consultant are insufficient to finish the remaining task. As a result, the project manager updates the ETC for the junior consultant from 5 hours to 8 hours. With the updated ETC, the EAC quantity for the junior consultant increases from 10 hours to 13 hours, resulting in the EAC costs increasing from 500 EUR to 650 EUR.

Figure 4 Adjust EAC values in the app ‚ÄúReview Customer Projects‚Äù

To update the EAC values in Financials (ACDOCP), the project manager uses the Transfer Project Forecast app to schedule a recurring job to update the EAC values for ongoing projects.

Remark on the planned revenue: their calculation is done dependent on the contract type. For a fixed price project plan revenue is taken from billing plan. In the case of T&E billing, billing simulation is carried out to determine the planned revenues based on the EAC costs.

Figure 5 Transfer Project Forecast to Finance

The job has been successfully executed for the example project. The updated forecasting data can now be reviewed in the Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services app.

Figure 6 Display EAC planned data in the app Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services

For customer projects, the planned data (baseline, ongoing, EAC, EBRR) is consistently updated within the leading ledger. Consequently, in the Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Service app, the planned data can be viewed by selecting the leading ledger in the global filter.

The plan category PRO03 serves as the source for the planned data related to the revenue recognition key SPTMSR for the T&E billing &PoC-based revenue recognition method. Please refer to the blog post: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/customer-projects-with-t-amp-e-billing-amp-poc-based-revenue-recognition/ba-p/13771327 for more details.

EBRR Planned Data

EBRR planned data (plan category REVREC01) represents the planned/EAC data/, which was used in Event-Based Revenue Recognition period-end calculation. When you run period-end close or you use the EBRR monitor app and save the revalued data, this plan category is updated with the used plan amounts for the selected period.

While the 3 plan categories shown above have always only one amount (as previous plan updates are deleted with a new plan update) the EBRR plan data is  kept per period. This allows you to analyze which EAC data was used for a previous period-end calculation.

In this example, the project uses the revenue recognition key SPFC, which applies the fixed-price, cost-based percentage-of-completion (POC) method. In the configuration activity Maintain Settings for Event-Based Revenue Recognition (ID 102530), the planned data source is set to strategy 306.

This means that Event-based EBRR uses EAC data only if there was an update in the Review Customer Project app (confirmed EAC), otherwise the current CPM plan data are read, and no ACDOCP entries are used.

At period-end EBRR uses the dynamic EAC by simulating the functionality of the Review Customer Project app. In which cases dynamic EAC can differ to original CPM plan see above. If there was an update in the Review Customer Project app, this is taken.

Figure 7 Source for Plan Values in the Configuration Activity Maintain Settings for Event-Based Revenue Recognition (ID 102530)

According to the configuration, in this example the real-time event-based revenue recognition is calculated using the confirmed EAC from the CPM planning applications (1150 EUR). Selecting ‚ÄúRevalue‚Äù recalculates the recognized revenue based on the dynamic EAC costs‚Äîwhich in this example equals the confirmed EAC‚Äîand is 1300 EUR.

Figure 8 Revalue in the Event-Based Revenue Recognition ‚Äì Projects app

Additionally, the first revaluation creates an EBRR planned data snapshot (plan category REVREC01). This snapshot is updated at each revaluation / period-end closing to capture the latest dynamic EAC for period-end closing calculations. The planned data is updated in the Event-Based Revenue Recognition ‚Äì Projects app.

Figure 9 EBRR Planned Data in the Event-Based Revenue Recognition ‚Äì Projects app

The EBRR planned data is now visible in the Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services app as . During the revaluation or period-end closing, EBRR posts the delta of the EAC to the corresponding period of the revaluation/period-end close. In the Event-Based Revenue Recognition ‚Äì Projects app, the aggregated value is always displayed. In the Project Financial Booklet, you can choose to view data up to the current period or leave the periods unselected to see the aggregated EBRR planned data.

Figure 10 Display EBRR Planned Data in the Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services app

Manual Planned Data

The plan categories above are calculated by the system based on the resource planning and billing information. With 2502 you can create an own plan category for projects. The manual planned data is characterized by the fact that it is recorded based on cost elements without reference to resource planning. They can be recorded in the SAP S/4HANA system by the Import Financial Plan Data app, through API or by transfer from SAC.

The manual plan category can we created in configuration activity (ID 101970)

Figure 11 Configuration for manual plan category

Usage 4 allows a manual planning.

With the assignment of application type ‚ÄúProject Management‚Äù, the following additional checks and derivation logic are provided during the update in ACDOCP:

  • A WBS element must be provided for every planning line item. This prevents an accidental deletion of planned data provided for other projects, which can happen when you use a periodic plan category like PLN.
  • The account assignment type ‚ÄúWBS element‚Äù is determined for all planning line items. This leads to subsequent derivation of additional attributes from the project and the assigned sales order item. For example, the profit center from the WBS billing element and the margin analysis fields from the sales order item are derived and stored for the planning line items.

Recommendation: use for your manual planning an own plan category with application type ‚Äúproject management‚Äù , and not a periodic plan category like PLN.

When you use the import app, you must provide a CSV File, which you can see here:

Figure 12 File for plan data import

The columns with the X in line 3 define the plan data scope: these fields must be filled, otherwise you get an error, and the plan data cannot be updated. Additional this is the scope, which is checked for project plan categories: if an X is missing, the import is rejected.

 You can define the fiscal year and period, and you can select company code or transaction currency. The currencies that are not provided, including global currency and object currency, are determined and translated by the ACDCOP update. The exchange rate type is defined in the plan category (see above) and the currency date is the first of the entered period.

For a project in a foreign currency,  you can enter the plan data in a transaction currency that is equal to the project currency.

 When using plan data in EBRR you need at least one revenue and one expense/cost G/L account line item. In the configuration activity Maintain Settings for Event-Based Revenue Recognition, you can set this custom plan category as the source of planned values for EBRR processing (source 500) for the allowed cost-based POC revenue recognition keys.

In the Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services app, use the page filter to select your custom planning category, then add the measures Planned Revenue Manual, Planned Cost Manual, and Planned Margin Manual to display the externally imported planned data for customer projects.

Figure 13 Display Imported Planned Data in the Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services app

Virtual Plan Category

For aggregation of the amount of several plan categories you can use a virtual plan category

Figure 14 Configuration for virtual plan category

There is an own application type ‚Äú8 Virtual plan category‚Äù available.

In configuration you can assign the plan categories to the virtual plan category (config ID 106876)

Figure 15 Configuration for assigning plan categories to virtual plan category

Please note there are no ACDOCP entries for the virtual plan category! You can enter the virtual plan category in the reporting as plan category: the report will read all assigned plan categories and aggregate the values. Additional you can assign the virtual plan category in EBRR as source for plan.

The virtual plan category could help you to move from periodic plan category PLN to a manual project plan category.

Conclusion

 Understanding and effectively monitoring planned data across various plan categories is essential for driving successful customer projects. In this blog, we have outlined the definitions, calculations, and currency conversions for key plan categories, including Baseline Planned Data (PRO01), Ongoing Planned Data (PRO02), EAC Planned Data (PRO03), EBRR Planned Data (REVREC01), Manual Plan Category, and Virtual Plan Category. By leveraging the Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services app, you can gain enhanced visibility across planning versions, enabling better budget control, profitability tracking, and alignment of plans with actuals.

entry.title: From Data to Decisions: How SAP SuccessFactors People Intelligence is Transforming HR Analytics
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs rapidly changing business landscape, organizations are looking to their people‚Äînot just as resources but as strategic assets. To stay competitive, HR leaders need more than ‚Äúheadcount‚Äù numbers; they need data they can trust, insights they can act on, and the agility to anticipate future workforce challenges.

This is where SAP SuccessFactors People Intelligence enters the picture‚Äîa modern analytics and insights platform designed to unify HR, skills, and business data into actionable intelligence. In this blog, we‚Äôll explore what People Intelligence is, its key capabilities, the business value it delivers, what to watch out for, and how to get started.

What is SAP SuccessFactors People Intelligence?

SAP‚Äôs People Intelligence is a next‚Äêgeneration analytics solution built on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). It is intended to replace or augment ‚Äútraditional‚Äù workforce analytics by providing unified, harmonized people & skills data, AI-driven insights, predictive analytics, and self-service dashboards for HR and business leaders.

Key Capabilities:
  • Prebuilt dashboards & KPIs: Hundreds of out-of-the-box workforce metrics across domains (recruiting, performance, learning, etc.).
  • AI / Predictive Forecasting: Forecast future workforce trends like skills gaps, attrition risk, and labor costs.
  • Natural Language Interface (Joule): Ask questions in plain language and get answers instantly.
  • Scenario Models / Simulations: Perform what-if analyses to test different workforce strategies.
  • Cross-functional Data Integration: Combine HR data with finance and operational datasets for holistic insight.
  • Skills & Growth Portfolio: Track skills, proficiency levels, and development paths for each employee.
Best Practices for Implementation:
  • Define clear objectives and business questions.
  • Ensure data readiness and standardization.
  • Establish governance and ownership for HR data.
  • Start with pilot projects and iterate.
  • Enable and train stakeholders across HR and management.
  • Foster a data-driven decision culture.
  • Ensure privacy and ethical data use.
Getting Started: What You Should Expect:

Adopting People Intelligence involves data integration, defining KPIs, setting up user roles, and enabling users through training and iterative rollout. Success comes from starting small, showing quick wins, and expanding progressively.

Real‚ÄêWorld Scenarios & Examples:
  • Using People Intelligence to identify and close data science skill gaps in a specific region.
  • Simulating hiring strategies for new market expansion.
  • Predicting and mitigating attrition risks with targeted retention strategies.
  • Linking workforce costs to revenue to demonstrate ROI of HR initiatives.
The State of Adoption & What‚Äôs New:

As of 2025, People Intelligence is available within SAP Business Data Cloud, featuring prebuilt insights for Recruiting, Learning, and Performance. It integrates Joule‚Äîthe AI copilot‚Äîand complements the Talent Intelligence Hub for skills data management.

Conclusion:

SAP SuccessFactors People Intelligence redefines how organizations use HR data‚Äîfrom reporting the past to predicting and shaping the future. For HR teams, it‚Äôs an opportunity to bring strategic value to the table, aligning people strategy with business outcomes.

Useful Resources:

https://www.sap.com/products/hcm/data-cloud.html

https://news.sap.com/2025/09/future-proofing-your-business-with-people-intelligence/

https://help.sap.com/docs/PEOPLE_INTELLIGENCE/2e4208869d8c40359aac93cf2f071e48/33fa21241c694bd987971264407f0211.html?parentHref=https://help.sap.com/whats-new/8fcf4960eea24f78b1d7613da406a885&parentName=SAP+SuccessFactors+What%27s+New

entry.title: Re: Common configuration issues: Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
entry.content:
As a first step check in detail if authentication using principal propagation works correctly.

Enable full tracing in Cloud Connector and check the trace file, look for your identity there. Make sure it's correctly passed to backend.

Enable tracing in backen in tr. SMICM and verify if correct identity is received from Cloud Connector and if authentication is correct - make sure authentication happens in the correct client.

entry.title: SAP BUILD Issue with Budget Approval Template ‚Äì Missing Field in POST api API_FINPLANNINGDATA_SRV
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We‚Äôre currently working with the Budget Approval Template:
Workflow Budget Approval

At the end of the process, it performs a POST to the API_FINPLANNINGDATA_SRV service:
API_FINPLANNINGDATA_SRV

Initially, we faced an error related to the company field, which we resolved by following this note:
üîó SAP Note 3550655 - Company field issue

Now, we‚Äôre encountering a Budget error. After following this note and testing directly in Postman, the POST works correctly:
üîó SAP Note 3564398 - Budget error resolution

However, the issue is that the field PlanDataRplcScopeFieldsString is not available in the Build Action because it‚Äôs missing in the POST schema.
This means SAP Build currently doesn‚Äôt allow us to send this field, even though it‚Äôs required ‚Äî so it seems the POST definition and the template need to be updated by SAP.

At this point, it looks like my only workaround is to create a new custom action in Build Process Automation and manually include this field in the POST body.

Has anyone found another solution or workaround for this issue?

PS: The Build Automation template also has a mapping error when approval is not needed ‚Äî the POST mapping is incorrect in that case as well.

Thanks in advance for any insights!

entry.title: LGM Knowledge Snippet: How do we determine carriers (as of now...)
entry.content:
One of the very basic ideas in SAP Logistics Management is to have super stable, well defined processes. This principle of course also applies to the way we determine carriers, so I want to explain a bit on that with some left and write comments on related topics. This posting describes our current state and we plan to improve in quite some of the described areas, but this is what we have today.

Relevance of carriers for the processes

For most of the shipping processes we support in LGM so far, the carrier is a prerequisite to start the process, including the warehousing. The idea here is, that for picking, labelling, staging it is necessary to already know the carrier when starting the warehouse processing.(yes, we know there are other scenarios and we plan to add them step by step, being cloud native allows us to do this step by step). Hence, the carrier determination is key to start the process.

Getting Carrier Integrated

Carriers (as well as other business partners ) are integrated using so called Replication Configuration. Basically, we pull the parties from the connected S/4 with either a scheduled job, or ad-hoc. A business partner needs the role "Carrier"(CRM010)  assigned to be considered as a carrier (again, this might be generalized in future). For some Shipping Processes like Parcel or Direct LTL, there also needs to be an external identification of the carrier maintained, e.g. the BN4L ID.

Carrier Determination process

So far, the carrier determination is following the following steps. The steps are so far always executed as described below, we plan to add some flexibility here in future. Once a carrier is determined in one of the steps, the processing is continued and the carrier cannot be changed anymore.

Check for carrier coming from S/4

If the S/4 delivery has a carrier assigned already it is taken over and carrier determination is over. At the moment, the partner function to be used is good old U3, this might be extended in future to other partner functions.

.

Rules Based Carrier Determination

If there is no carrier defined in the delivery, we use Carrier Determination using the carrier determination business rule, the rule id is CARRIER_DETN_V1.  The currently available input parameters can be found in the linked documentation, we strongly recommend using the Shipping point rather than the source location. In the rule, the displayId of the carrier must be maintained. (yes, currently, we don have search helps and validations in place, we plan to improve here, of course üôÇ )

In the example the carrier LGMCARR1 is determined based on the ship to party displayId:

 

 

 

 

 

 

For reference, this is where you find the ID in the business partner UI:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

No worries, if the carrier determination is not maintained for all cases, there is some fallback available, which will follow in the next steps.

Tendering based Carrier Determination

If the previous step did not determine a carrier, we have something special in place for the Shipping Process we call Direct LTL. In this shipping process, the Tendering Process is started. As this opens up a world of it¬¥s own, I leave this for another posting...

Fallback: Enter Carrier manual

In case all the previous steps were failing, you can enter the carrier manually. This can be done either in the Transportation Request or the consignment(this depends on the Shipping Process you are using, more on that in another posting...).

The documents with missing carrier can be identified easily by a red icon in the progress overview (this is our overarching pattern here, if there is an error requiring your attention, this is indicated in the progress overview):

 

Here, you can just enter the carrier manually.

 

Finally, of course you can also ask Joule about the process üôÇ

entry.title: Developing Mobile Apps with AI Agents: Introducing the MCP Server for mobile development kit
entry.content:
Are you an experienced developer working on mobile app projects based on SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK)? Do you want to jumpstart your mobile app development with MDK?  Do you use AI agents such as Cursor, Cline, OpenCode, or GitHub Copilot to support you in your daily work? Wouldn't it be cool if the agent could help you develop MDK applications? We now offer some free tools that can provide more context about your project as well as relevant MDK examples to steer the AI coding assistant in doing the right thing.

Figure 1: High level overview MDK MCP Server

 We are excited to announce the release of the MCP server for mobile development kit. This open-source server provides AI agents with comprehensive MDK knowledge and tools. By combining best practice guidelines, project-aware context information, templates for creating new projects, and access to the MDK CLI tools, the MDK MCP server transforms AI agents into MDK development experts.

The code repository is located at  https://github.com/SAP/mdk-mcp-server

This MDK specific release follows previously announced MCP servers by SAP for:

  • CAP
  • Fiori
  • UI5

What is an MCP Server?

An Model Context Protocol (MCP) server is designed to manage and deliver capabilities to Large Language Models (LLMs) via AI agents. It bridges the gap between LLMs and external resources such as services, tools, and data, enabling LLMs to interact with these resources.

What is mobile development kit?

The SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK) is a powerful framework that enables developers to build cross-platform mobile applications using a metadata-driven approach. It is part of SAP Business Technology Platform and integrates tightly with SAP Mobile Services.

Some of SAP‚Äôs larger and complex mobile apps are built using MDK. An example is SAP Service and Asset Manager.

Why should you use this MCP server?

The newly introduced MCP server for mobile development kit transforms AI agents into MDK development experts. It provides context-focused tools that aim to help the AI agent to answer questions such as:

  • Finding examples of using an MDK component.
  • Retrieving details about specific properties of an MDK component.
  • Finding the schema for a specific MDK component.
  • Searching MDK documentation.

Other reasons for using this MCP server:

  • Large Language Models (LLMs) sometimes lack information on the latest best practices and metadata recommended for MDK development.
  • They might recommend the use of MDK metadata that does not exist in the version your project is using, or MDK metadata that has been marked as deprecated.
  • By facilitating MDK validation tools, your coding agent can validate the changes it has made, ensuring it follows current best practices.
  • Scaffolding tools can help agents kickstart new projects faster and with established patterns, saving token costs.

The MCP server can help you answer questions you as a developer have about the project you are working on, such as:

  • Explain what this specific file does in the MDK project structure.
  • How can I use Fragments in my project?
  • Can this application support offline capabilities?
  • Are there any requirements for the data source to support offline?

Combining AI agents with existing tools ‚Äì a powerful and efficient combination

Instead of relying fully on what an AI agent can generate, we offer the agent access to existing tools in our MDK toolset.

Figure 2: Tools used by the MCP Server for mobile development kit

With MDK tools, we can migrate, validate, build and deploy projects. With the MDK Generator, we provide project scaffolding for Base, Empty, List-Detail and CRUD templates. Based on your prompts, we can further generate pages and actions to your MDK project. This ensures a more predictable outcome, saves time and tokens (costs).

Open Source

We are also happy to announce that the MCP Server for mobile development kit is an open-source project, licensed under the Apache-2.0 license. Learn more about open source at SAP.

We are curious to see what you will do with our MCP server for mobile development kit ! Please do not hesitate to provide your feedback here or report any issues in our GitHub repository.

Setup

Assuming you have already installed node.js on your machine, first install Yeoman. This must be an older version of Yeoman to avoid compatibility issues.

npm install -g yo@4.3.1

For installing the MDK MCP server, we will soon offer a way to install it from npmjs. Until then, please use the following steps to clone the open-source code repository at https://github.com/SAP/mdk-mcp-server, and use npm to install it:

git clone https://github.com/SAP/mdk-mcp-server.git
cd mdk-mcp-server
npm i --include=optional

npm i -g /mdk-mcp-server@.‚Äã

Both MDK Tools (@sap/mdk-tools) as well as MDK Generator (@sap/generator-mdk) will automatically be installed as dependencies of the MCP server for mobile development kit.

Next, your MCP client (AI agent) needs to be configured to make use of the server. Depending on the AI agent used, the configuration looks a little different. We are still waiting for alignment across AI agents regarding this kind of configuration.

In general, the mcpServers configuration should include the following section:

     "mdk-mcp": {
      "command": "mdk-mcp",
      "args": []
    }


Once installed, the AI agent in your IDE will automatically gain access to the MDK MCP server and can start using the tools at its own discretion. Depending on your IDE and settings, you may need to approve the first tool calls.

Figure 3: MCP Servers configuration in Cline

 

Rules

The following rules help guide the agent to use the server correctly.

## Guidelines for MDK
Don‚Äôt generate .service.metadata file
Don‚Äôt generate .xml file in ‚ÄòServices‚Äô folder
Don‚Äôt change .project.json file


Add these rules to your existing global or project-specific AGENTS.md (specifics may vary based on respective MCP client).

Figure 4: MDK specific rules configuration in Cline

 

Tools

This release of the MDK MCP server includes the following tools, which can be accessed by your AI agent:

Tool name

Description

mdk-gen-project

Generates a new MDK project in the current directory.

mdk-gen-i18n

Returns a prompt to generate i18n files for MDK project describing the texts, labels and messages.

mdk-gen-databinding-page

Returns a prompt to generate a databinding-enabled MDK page describing the page layout, controls and data bindings.

mdk-gen-layout-page

Generates a layout-based MDK page. You can describe the page layout, controls.

mdk-gen-entity

Generates CRUD or List Detail template metadata for a new entity set.

mdk-gen-action

Returns a prompt to generate an MDK action describing the action type and data bindings.

mdk-build

Build an MDK project.

mdk-deploy

Deploy an MDK project to SAP Mobile Services.

mdk-show-qrcode

Show QR code for an MDK application.

mdk-migrate

Migrate an MDK project to the latest MDK schema version.

mdk-validate

Validate an MDK project.

mdk-search-documentation

Returns the top N results from MDK documentation by semantic search, sorted by relevance.

mdk-get-component-documentation

Returns the schema of an MDK component based on the name of the component.

mdk-get-property-documentation

Returns the documentation of a specific property of an MDK component.

mdk-get-example

Returns an example usage of an MDK component.

mdk-open-mobile-app-editor

Returns instructions on how to open the Mobile App Editor to create the ‚Äú.service.metadata‚Äù file.

 

 

Integration with SAP Mobile Services

For the integration with SAP Mobile Services, the MCP server currently makes use of the Cloud Foundry CLI and a service metadata file that contains details about:

  1. The mobile application defined in the SAP Mobile Services instance.
  2. The OData service metadata of the data source used in the mobile application. This describes the data model and capabilities of the OData service.

An example of such a service metadata file (with filename ‚Äú.service.metadata‚Äù) is provided in our code repository. However, changing this file is not easy. We offer a tool to help with creating or updating this file as part of our Visual Studio Code extension: Mobile development kit extension for Visual Studio Code

How to use this tool to create or update the ‚Äú.service.metadata‚Äù file:

1. Install Mobile development kit extension for Visual Studio Code version 1.32.0 or later in your Visual Studio Code.

2. Make sure you have installed the Cloud Foundry CLI.

3. Make sure to log in to your SAP Business Technology Platform environment on Cloud Foundry. This can be done by executing the following command in a terminal window:

cf login <your target endpoint> --sso

For more details you can refer to this help documentation.

4. Open the Command Palette in Visual Studio Code and select the "MDK: Open Mobile App Editor" command.

Figure 5: MDK: Open Mobile App Editor

5. Create/Select a new/existing mobile app.

Figure 6: Mobile Application Editor in Visual Studio Code

6. Select a destination.

7. Click "Add App to Project" button.

We also offer a tool in the MCP server to provide you the above information through the agent. You can basically ask the agent how to create the ‚Äú.service.metadata‚Äù file.

In future releases we aim to enhance and further simplify the integration with SAP Mobile Services.

What can you do with this server?

The MCP server for mobile development kit works well for everyday tasks in MDK projects. It can help you refactor your code and metadata and add new features.

Important: Our MCP Server for mobile development kit is designed to support professional developers in their daily work. As with all AI-generated information, you should check the generated results carefully to avoid unintended side effects. As a professional developer, YOU are in control and responsible for the outcome.

Some examples where this MCP server can help

Update old projects

I‚Äôve opened an old project that I‚Äôve created in one of my previous blog post series. I know the MDK metadata schema is outdated and want to update it. I‚Äôll ask Cline which tool can be used for this. As you can see in the screenshot, Cline made use of the MCP server for MDK to find out which tool to be used and is now proactively asking to run the MDK migration tool.

Figure 7: Update old MDK project in Cline

Explain specific properties

In the screenshot below, I am using Cursor and asked what the property ‚ÄúAnimated‚Äù does in an Action.

Figure 8: Get explanation of a property in Cursor

Help to deploy the app

Making use of the available tools, the AI agent can help you deploy the mobile app and provide detailed information on how to install the app on your device.

Figure 9a: Deployment - validate and build the app in Cursor 

Figure 9b: Deployment - deploy and show QR code in Cursor 

Figure 9c: Deployment - Summary and installation instructions in Cursor

Conclusion

In this blog post we have introduced new tools to help professional developers in their everyday tasks developing MDK apps. We have made the tools as open as possible, to allow developers to use their favorite agentic development environment. As a developer, you should be able to develop SAP mobile apps in whatever environment you prefer to use.

We are also providing the MCP server as open source, allowing you to modify the tool to your needs and contribute enhancements.

As always, feedback is welcome to improve the blog posts, but most importantly the tools and products involved.

entry.title: Re: Auto Post Goods Issue
entry.content: You can configure an output type for outbound delivery that triggers a custom BAdI implementation SD_DELIVERY_OUTPUT or similar (depending on version). In your custom logic, you can call the released API like API_OUTBOUND_DELIVERY_SRV for posting goods issue. This approach allows you to simulate the behavior of auto-GI after OBD creation.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Change Deprecation Key in SAP S4HANA Public...
entry.content:
It is not allowed to change from a key that has deprec to the day to one that does not. 

Option 1 - create new legacy assets, reverse values off old asset and then post to the new assets.
Option 2 - create new legacy assets and transfer values from old legacy assets to new assets.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Change Deprecation Key in SAP S4HANA Public...
entry.content: the question is about changing the deprec key assigned to the legacy assets, not changing the customizing of the depreciation key.

entry.title: The Transformation Advisor: Bridging Business Challenges with Process Insights
entry.content:
What Is the Transformation Advisor?

The Transformation Advisor is an experimental innovation feature designed to help SAP Signavio users identify, understand, and act on business challenges using data-driven process intelligence.
It extracts key challenges from documents such as financial reports or manual inputs and links them directly to relevant process flows, best practices, and improvement content within the SAP Signavio ecosystem.

By doing so, the Transformation Advisor closes the gap between strategic business context and operational process management, helping users translate insights into tangible actions with just a few clicks.

How It Works

  1. Input: Upload a financial report or describe a business challenge. In the screenshots I used examples provided by SAP.

 

2. Challenge Extraction: The Transformation Advisor automatically identifies and summarizes key business challenges.

Optional Integration: Link a Process Insights tenant to enrich recommendations with process performance data. This is only possible if you have SAP Signavio Process Insights in use. 

3. Recommendation Generation: Receive tailored links to process flows, improvement opportunities, and innovation ideas. 

4. Export Results: Share insights and recommendations with stakeholders for further analysis and transformation planning.

Here you see some screenshots from a example report.

 

The Transformation Advisor represents the next step in intelligent business transformation. By combining AI-driven challenge analysis with the process intelligence of SAP Signavio, it empowers organizations to move seamlessly from identifying pain points to defining actionable improvement opportunities.

As part of the SAP Signavio Lab Space, this innovation is shaping the future of transformation management‚Äîbridging strategy and execution, and helping leaders make better decisions, faster.

Stay tuned for upcoming enhancements, including deeper integration with SAP Signavio Process Insights.

If you want to test this feature by your own: Here you find a link on how to activate the Lab Space in your SAP Signavio workspace. The SAP Signavio Lab Space functions as a co-innovation hub where customers can test new, experimental features ahead of general release.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Error during Upload of Pages
entry.content:
Hi @LukasKuhn

Those errors you see refer back to the fact that the page you exported the JSON file from has its original language set to German, but your target is to import it into an English tenant and therefore generating the errors. Here are a few details to consider:

  • As you mentioned, a manual recreation of the pages in your new tenant is the available option.
  • If both of your systems share the same CBC environment you have the option to use the copy function, it will ease the process.
  • What you tried with the JSON file and it not working out lies in the fact that directly editing JSON file is not supported.

Best regards

Chris
